question: Question_A_04
statement:
Consider

\[M = \begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & p & 5 \\ 1 & pq + 7 & 8 \end{bmatrix}\]

For what \emph{p} and \emph{q} does the matrix \emph{M} have rank 2?
sols:
\_\_NOTOC\_\_ We reduce the matrix to row-echelon form. Subtracting the
first row from the last row transforms

\[M = \begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & p & 5 \\ 1 & pq + 7 & 8 \end{bmatrix}\]

into

\[\begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & p & 5 \\ 0 & pq  & 5 \end{bmatrix}.\]

Now, subtracting the second row from the third row yields

\[\begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & p & 5 \\ 0 & pq-p  & 0 \end{bmatrix}\]

This matrix either has rank 2 or rank 3. If \emph{pq - p=p(q - 1) = 0},
then \emph{M} has rank 2; otherwise, \emph{M} has rank 3. In other
words, \emph{M} has rank 2 exactly when \emph{p=0} or \emph{q=1}.
hints:
What does it mean for the matrix to have rank 2? How can the row-echelon
form help you?

For a rank 2 matrix in row-echelon form, the first two rows must each
have at least 1 non-zero entry, while the last row must consist of zeros
only.
